tn.text: Paul continues to be a prisoner in Caesarea.
Festus becomes the governor of Caesarea. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:24:26|24:27]].
This word marks the beginning of a new event in the story.
Possible meanings are 1) Festus arrived in the area to begin his rule (UDB) or 2) Festus simply arrived in the area.

tn.ref: he went from Caesarea up to Jerusalem
tn.text: The phrase "went up" is used here because Jerusalem is higher in elevation than Caesarea.

tn.ref: the prominent Jews brought accusations against Paul to Festus
tn.text: This speaks about accusations as if they were an object that a person could bring to someone else. AT: "the important Jews accused Paul to Festus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"they begged Festus"

tn.ref: that he might call him ... so that they could kill him
tn.text: "that Festus might call Paul ... so that the Jews could kill Paul"
This means that Felix would order his soldiers to bring Paul to Jerusalem. AT: "that he might order his soldiers to bring Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: they could kill him along the way
tn.text: They were going to ambush Paul.
Here the word "us" refers to Festus and the Romans traveling with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: But Festus answered that Paul was a prisoner in Caesarea, and that he himself was soon to return there
tn.text: This can be stated as a direct quotation. AT: "But Festus said, 'Paul is a prisoner in Caesarea, and I myself will soon return there'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: "Therefore, those who can," he said, "should go there with us
tn.text: The phrase "he said" can be moved to the beginning of the sentence. AT: "Then he said, 'Therefore, those who are able to go to Caesarea should go there with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_quotations]])

tn.ref: If there is something wrong with the man
tn.text: "If Paul has done something wrong"
"you should accuse him of violating laws" or "you should bring charges against him"
Here the first three times the word "he" is used as well as the word "him," the words refer to Festus. The fourth word "he" refers to Paul.
The word "they" refers to the Jews who came from Jerusalem.
Jerusalem is higher geographically than Caesarea. It was common to speak of coming down from Jerusalem.
Here "judgment seat" refers to Festus' ruling as judge over Paul's trial. AT: "sat upon the seat where he acted as judge" or "he sat down as judge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Paul to be brought to him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "his soldiers bring Paul to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"When he came and stood before Festus"

Charging a person with a crime is spoken of as if it were an object that a person could bring to court. AT: "they spoke against Paul many serious things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul says he did not break any rules about who could enter the Jerusalem temple. AT: "against the entry rules of the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Paul asks to be taken before Caesar for judgment.

tn.ref: wanted to gain the favor of the Jews
tn.text: Here "the Jews" means the Jewish leaders. AT: "wanted to please the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jerusalem was higher geographically than Caesarea. It was common to speak of going up to Jerusalem.

tn.ref: and to be judged by me about these things there
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "where I will judge you with regard to these charges" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I stand before the judgment seat of Caesar where I must be judged
tn.text: The "judgment seat" refers to Caesar's authority to judge Paul. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I ask to go before Caesar, so he can judge me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Though if I have done wrong ... no one may hand me over to them
tn.text: Paul is stating a hypothetical situation. If he were guilty, he would accept the punishment, but he knows that he is not guilty. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: if I have done what is worthy of death
tn.text: "if I have done some wrong that deserves the death penalty"
"if the charges against me are not true"

tn.ref: no one may hand me over to them
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Festus does not have the legal authority to hand Paul over to these false accusers or 2) Paul was saying that if he has done nothing wrong, the governor should not give into the request of the Jews.
"I ask that I go before Caesar so he can judge me"
This is not the Sanhedrin that is referred to as "council" throughout Acts. This is a political council in the Roman government. AT: "with his own government advisors"
Festus explains Paul's case to King Agrippa.

King Agrippa and Bernice are new people in the story. Though he ruled over only a few territories, King Agrippa is the current reigning king in Palestine. Bernice is Agrippa's sister.(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This word marks the beginning of a new event in the story.

tn.ref: to pay an official visit to Festus
tn.text: "to visit Festus concerning official matters"

tn.ref: A certain man was left behind here by Felix as a prisoner
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "When Felix left office, he left a man in prison here" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Felix was the Roman governor of the area who resided in Caesarea. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:23:22|23:24]].

tn.ref: brought charges against this man to me
tn.text: To charge someone in court is spoken of as if it were an object that a person brings to court. AT: "spoke to me against this man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they asked for condemnation against him
tn.text: The abstract noun "condemnation" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "they asked me to condemn him to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"to condemn a man to death"
"to meet directly with his those who accuse him"
This word marks a statement because of what was said previously. In this case, Fetus had just said that an accused man should be able to face his accusers and make his defense.
"when the Jewish leaders came to meet with me here"

tn.ref: I sat in the judgment seat
tn.text: Here "judgment seat" refers to Festus ruling over Paul's trial as judge. AT: "I sat upon the seat to act as judge" or "I sat down as judge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I ordered the man to be brought in
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I ordered the soldiers to bring Paul before me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "religion" means the belief system people have toward life and the supernatural.

tn.ref: to be judged there about these things
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "where the Jewish council would decide if he were guilty of these charges" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Festus finishes explaining Paul's case to King Agrippa.

tn.ref: But when Paul called to be kept under guard for the emperor's decision
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But when Paul insisted that he stay under Roman guard so the emperor could decide his case" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I ordered him to be kept
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I told the soldiers to keep him in prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The phrase "Festus said" can be moved to the beginning of the sentence. AT: "Festus said, 'I will arrange for you to listen to Paul tomorrow'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_quotations]])
Festus again gives information about Paul's case to King Agrippa.
Though he ruled over only a few territories, Agrippa was the current reigning king in Palestine. Bernice was his sister. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:act:25:13|25:13]].
"with a great ceremony to honor them"
This was a large room where people gathered for ceremonies, trials, and other events.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the soldiers brought Paul to appear before them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an exaggeration used for emphasis. AT: "many of the Jews" or "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"they spoke very strongly to me"
This statement is made in the negative to emphasize the positive equivalent. AT: "he should die immediately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Here the first "you" is plural; the second "you" is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: because he called upon the emperor
tn.text: "because he asked for the emperor to judge him"

tn.ref: I have brought him to you, especially to you, King Agrippa
tn.text: "I have brought Paul to all of you, but especially to you, King Agrippa."

tn.ref: so that I might have something more to write
tn.text: "so that I will have something else to write" or "so that I will know what I should write"

tn.ref: it seems unreasonable for me to send a prisoner and to not also state
tn.text: The negative words "unreasonable" and "to not" can be stated in positive form. AT: "it seems reasonable to me that if I send a prisoner then I should also state" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Possible meanings are 1) the accusations that the Jewish leaders have brought against him or 2) the charges under Roman law that apply to Paul's case.
